A layman's guide to good passwords online

  • Tutorial
  • 01 May 2015
  • About 8 minutes

We have a problem with passwords: they suck. They’re hard to memorise, easy to steal and sometimes have to fit to very specific and silly rules. Online security, nowadays, is just too complicated. So most people tend to end up ignoring security practises, making them vulnerable to cyberattacks. You know you should be doing better, but you don’t know exactly how or why, and your patience and energy are better focused somewhere else, right? If so, then this guide is for you.

Read more...

Setting up a hacker's blog with Jekyll, part 2

  • Tutorial
  • 13 Mar 2015
  • About 11 minutes

Feeling like building your new bog from scratch with tools that empower you to develop it the way you want? You’ve come to the right place. If you’re just starting, make sure you read part 1 of this tutorial, where you can learn the advantages of using Jekyll over other options and how to use it to create a basic blog from scratch. In this second part we’ll be working with the same blog example code to extend it and make it more interesting. However, if you’re just looking for a particular solution to a problem you might have with your existing blog, these examples should be self-contained enough.

Read more...

More Semantic Web for Ruby: mastering your data

  • Tutorial
  • 15 Feb 2015
  • About 11 minutes

In a previous post I shared some important tips and resources for anyone who plans on developing for the Semantic Web in Ruby (like in a Ruby on Rails webapp). If you haven’t checked it yet, I strongly recommend you to do so. This new post goes a step further and shows you how to convert data from the Semantic Web to your app’s data model and also the other way around.

Developing for the Semantic Web with Ruby on Rails, the 2012 guide

  • Tutorial
  • 08 Feb 2015
  • About 10 minutes

The Semantic Web, an Internet of of connected knowledge, meaningful data and machine-readable information, is seen as many as the future of the Internet. Envisioned by Tim Berners-Lee, its purpose is to transition from a web of unstructured documents into a “web of data”, in which we could browse and search for data not only based on syntactic keywords, but also based on semantic meaning. However, it’s awkward to realise that most of the work around the Semantic Web is done in Java, and many technologies with great future potential, such as Ruby on Rails, are seemingly forgotten.

Read more...

Setting up a hacker's blog with Jekyll

  • Tutorial
  • 01 Feb 2015
  • About 9 minutes

If you’re looking for a blogging platform or framework to start sharing your thoughts with the rest of the world, there’s no shortage of options to consider. My previous blog was a self-hosted Wordpress install, a pretty popular option, which turned out to be a disaster for me. Other popular options include regular Wordpress, Medium or even Tumblr. However, if you want your blog to exercise your hacking skills, then Jekyll is the way to go.
